segments.Text:
This text was transcribed using whisper model: large-v2

 Hello there. Welcome to this talk. This is The Dog Ate My Homework. I talk about PowerShell
and Bloodhound. This is a talk I gave at SoCon a few months ago, but I had to re-record it
because something went wrong back then. So you get an updated version of the talk.
So I'll start with the classical, who am I, but I'll start with a few memes just to give
credit to Rohan and Andy for Bloodhound and all the team working at Bloodhound. Then I'll
quickly introduce myself. So I'm a SAT processor online known as Walter Ligowski, born in France,
living in Holland, father of three. I used to work for ERNW in Germany. Maybe you know
them from the Troopers Conference, highly recommended. Then I moved to Falcon Force
here in Holland. I say hi to the good folks at Falcon Force. I'm now working at Spector
Ops for the Bloodhound team. So I'm a big fan of PowerShell and I'll be showing some
of that PowerShell today. And back in the days, I had written the Dog Whisperer handbooks,
which was a bit of an unofficial guide to Bloodhound. And maybe you know these tools.
So CypherDog was my attempt at talking to the legacy Bloodhound REST API and sending
some Cypher there. Then I wrote Watchdog, which was an attempt at putting metrics out
of Bloodhound queries. A big pain point was ZipHound, my attempt at trying to automate
ingestion of the data in the legacy, which was a complicated task, let's put it that way. So
super happy this is now possible over the API in the new Bloodhound. And then my most recent
attempt at connecting Bloodhound to other tools was working on FalconHound during my
Falcon Force days. Along with Olaf, we tried to connect Bloodhound to the SIEM. But then
the new Bloodhound came out. And so all those tools that I had written over the years
were kind of deprecated, even though CypherDog would still work. But I still decided to write
a new tool to talk to the new Bloodhound. And this is what I'll be presenting in this talk.
So the agenda slightly modified compared to the original SoCalm talk. The intro,
that's what we're doing now. Then I added a little bit of a demo of the install, which I
didn't do during the original talk. I just wanted to be sure everything would work. So I skipped
that. But here I can show you that. While everything is installing, we're going to go
into a bit of slides. And I'll explain the main differences between the old and the new Bloodhound.
Then I'll dive into the new Bloodhound REST API, show you how that works,
how you can authenticate to it, and make some requests. And then, yeah, the biggest part of
the talk will be a purely demo of the PowerShell module, and then a conclusion.
So let's get right into it, starting with the first demo. And that's for the install. Let me
probably clear the screen. So I want to show you first
Dockers. I explained a bit in the slide the whole installation. But let's say if you want
to install Bloodhound, you start with the Docker desktop here on Windows. And I just want to show
you that I have just a fresh equivalent of a fresh install of Dockers with no images,
no containers, no volumes yet. And we're going to install all this.
Let me grab my demo. So yeah, maybe before I start, I show you the code for the tool and where
you can find it. So I'll share this. It's on a GIS for now. I'll share the link via the Bloodhound
Slack. I get that you can't really copy that from the screen here. But let's say if I was to
go there. So it's on a GIS for now. You will find this as the Bloodhound operator preview.
Yeah, and basically it's a flat file with all the commandlets in there. So one download,
load this in your session, and you would be good to go. So with the module comes a few commands
to deploy it. So let's have a look at how that would work. So let's say I would load the module.
Then I can say new bh-composer. I'm going to give it the name of a folder.
So this simply creates the folder and downloads the necessary file for the Docker. So if I cd into
that, you will see that here I have this Docker compose file. And all I have to do to install it
is say Docker composer up. And we're going to see it start pulling the images.
While this is all downloading, I'm just going to switch to the slide and explain a bit. But you do
see that it's probably if you went through the pain of installing the legacy Bloodhound,
then you see that that's a really easy fix. So back to the slides.
While it's installing, I'm going to explain a bit. So old Bloodhound versus new Bloodhound.
Here I want to detail a bit the components, how the applications were made and is made now,
and what the differences and what that implies in terms of interacting with the application.
So for the old Bloodhound, I guess you're familiar with it, but it used to be that you downloaded
Neo4j community with matching JDK before that. And once you had that installed,
you could simply click the Bloodhound binaries to get the UI opened up.
So basically Bloodhound was just an interface between Neo4j and the user basically.
It came with its own browser and the REST API. So you could talk to the Neo4j browser
directly. That was handy to get some, let's say some objects back or some
tables. And then you could talk to the REST API to send some Cypher queries. And this is what
CypherDog, my previous tool used to do. And this is around CypherDog that I had built all the
other tools basically. Now in the new Bloodhound, the UI looks very familiar.
If you've been using legacy, there's a few differences, nothing major on that side.
It's more in the way it's composed behind the difference. Everything now lives in Dockers.
And not only do you have the Bloodhound image, but you will also have a Neo4j and a PostgreSQL
images for the install. So there are now two backing database.
Bloodhound itself has its own REST API. So that's a difference compared to the legacy Bloodhound
where actually the REST API was a Neo4j REST API, but Bloodhound itself did not have any.
So you could not interact with the application itself. Here, Bloodhound is fully based around
the REST API. So whatever you do in the Bloodhound UI is actually calling the REST API that interacts
with the backing databases. This is where the automation is going to happen with the new
Bloodhound operators. Everything will be talking to this new REST API. In Bloodhound community,
you can still expose the Neo4j and SQL container and interact directly with them. That's probably
mostly for advanced users and not really needed since you can do about everything almost via the
Bloodhound REST API itself. So like I said, this is the path for the new tooling. And we'll see
that covers all aspects of the application. I wouldn't recommend if you're building toolings
or I, or it's not recommended, I guess, to use the, to talk to Neo4j directly,
even though you can do it. And for the reason being that Neo4j will be removed
or is being slowly phased out. And so in a future Bloodhound will be completely Neo4j free.
Don't worry though, you can still use Cypher. I'll come back to that later.
So in terms of feature, easy install compared to the legacy. That's something we'll see
at the end of those slides, hopefully everything installed correctly.
A complete new possibility is user management in the new Bloodhound enterprise or community.
You can have several users with different roles and I'll develop a bit on that later.
More secure authentication when communicating to the API. It used to be basic out for the
legacy Bloodhound. We now have a more robust authentication mechanism. And I'll also explain
that in the next slides. Both support custom Cypher queries. The difference here being that
in the legacy, we would run Cypher directly against Neo4j. So that allowed for the full
Cypher language. For now in the new Bloodhound, the Cypher language vocabulary or syntax that
you're allowed to use is limited. Let's put it that way. I think that the engineering team is
working on a full solution that would allow you to cover the full grammar. So also a mutation
that's been added. I'm not going to demo it today, but it's a very fresh feature.
So as we move in time, the parity or the functionalities will be more or less all
implemented. And you can use any type of Cypher language you used to use in legacy
in the new Bloodhound. But that's still, so that's why there's an asterisk might still
not be the case right now, but it's in the development. One big plus for me,
because my goal was to kind of automate the full process around Bloodhound from ingestion to
analysis and querying the data. A pain point in legacy was the ingestion where you had to
drag and drop this CSV into the application for the ingestion to start. And like I said,
I tried to build my own version of importing it via Neo4j over the REST API, but that's been like
trying to catch a train at full speed since Captain Jesus was adding features and features
and features. So I'm happy now it's possible over the REST API and I'll show you how in the demo.
And then other actions via the REST API. So legacy, the only thing you could do really was
talk to a Neo4j and send a Cypher to it. So query the data. Here, I'll show you that you can control
all aspects of the application via the REST API. And then the last killer feature, if you needed
one to kind of help you make the move to the new Bloodhound. I know some of you out there still
using the old one. I've seen the amount of questions on the Bloodhound stack. So yeah,
for me, another good reason to move to the new Bloodhound is all the ADCS nodes and attack path
being added to the new Bloodhound. So you will not get that if you're still using
the old Bloodhound, which would be a shame. So that's my meme to try to convince you.
Now let's talk a bit about the REST API itself. So like I said, the new Bloodhound has a full
blown REST API, exposes all functionalities of the UI, follows OpenAPI spec, secure authentication.
It's the same way if you're using Bloodhound Community or Enterprise. The only difference is
the number of endpoints you're allowed to talk to depending what version you're using. And it's all
explorable in the UI with the API Explorer. So that's a little screenshot on the side of what
it looks like when you want to try to see what's possible via the API in the application itself.
I can show you that also a bit later. So like I said, in the application, you have user management
now. So you can have several roles and each role has different permissions, which in terms will
condition what API endpoint you're allowed to talk to. So we do see the full I can do everything
admin. We have a power user. We have a regular user. They have various level of access. And then
two interesting ones I find for automation or connecting Bloodhound to other things would be
this upload only role and the read only role. So these are super nice addition, in my opinion,
to the tool. And like I said, you can see also there's some of these endpoints or roles are
only allowed in enterprise. So depending if you're a user using enterprise in community,
this sums up basically what you can do in the application itself.
When it comes to authentication to the REST API, so like I said,
used to be basic auth in the old Bloodhound. Here we use a triple eight max signature for
every request. I'll show you how that looks in code in a second. But basically,
when you want to talk to the API, you create a token in the application that's composed of a
token ID and a token key. Each request has to be signed with a token key, the operation, a timestamp
and the body itself. So the bytes of all this used to do a triple check. And this prevents
replay at a later date for a different operation with a different body or from a different
user, basically. And then the server validates signature against each request.
I can show you here in the Bloodhound documentation.
Let me take that back here. So here in the Bloodhound documentation, you will find an example
code for working with the API in Python. So if you're a Python fan, this is where you could start
looking at to build your own Python tooling. I'm a PowerShell fan, like I said, so I'm going to show
you the PowerShell version of it. Oops. So this is the code I use in the Bloodhound operator for
the signature. So you just see, we take the timestamp, we take the bytes of the key, the
bytes of the method, so get, post and so on. And the URI we talk to, take the bytes of the date
and take the bytes of the body. And we do three times this hash computation and we put it as a
base64 string that becomes our signature. And we include this signature with the timestamp and the
token ID in the headers and we invoke REST method after that. So the code, it gets complicated to do
that at every request you want to do manually. So here you have to build this little wrapper function
that does this for you. And this is basically what the whole Bloodhound operator module is
built around. So it takes care of the whole signature every time for you. You just have to give
your token key token ID once, then every call you make during that session will be signed
and properly, basically. So now the module itself, the tool that I'm presenting here,
called it the Bloodhound operator, because that's what it's made for. Maybe I should have found
something better. I don't know if you have ideas. It's a set of PowerShell cmdlets for the
Bloodhound REST API. If you're using community, there's around 60 cmdlets that will work
for community functionality. And if you're using enterprise, you get about 80 cmdlets.
There's other objects you can manipulate, basically. Every cmdlet follows this verb-noun syntax
with a little bh prefix in front. So it's going to be get bh something, set bh something, remove bh
something. And yeah, everything I love in PowerShell. So everything output objects. You get pipeline input
cross-platform. So this module should run on Windows, Linux, and macOS. I'd be happy to hear
feedback from macOS users, because I don't have much yet. So might be some things I need to fix
around the macOS. Let me know. All application features are available. So all
endpoints, API endpoints, are covered. And it allows for, yeah, whatever you want to do with
Bloodhound. But you could do scripted deployments. If you're a red team and you want to
deploy your users, you could have a CSV and automate the deployment of those users every
time you deploy a new Bloodhound instance. You could do, I don't know, automated queries against
the database and produce a report after that. So basically, this module is just a way to talk to
Bloodhound. And I hope people use it and the whole PowerShell ecosystem around it to kind of
build some even cooler stuff. Yeah. And it does here allow for the full ingest query and analyze
with a bit more automation on the community or DIY on the community side, of course.
But since now you can ingest, run queries, you could automate this whole process.
And yeah, I put it here as an expanded experimental feature. But you could even
have multiple sessions. So be talking to multiple Bloodhound instances at the same time.
It's probably more useful for us internally than for, I don't know, whoever. I don't know.
Quick disclaimer before we jump into the demo. This is still a work in progress.
I didn't expect it to be that big. But yeah, the API is quite,
has a lot of functionalities. So slowly I covered, I believe, almost everything.
But yeah, I'm still a work in progress. Some things are missing. So I'm hoping I will add
this shortly, mostly around setting up single sign on. Some things will change. So I wouldn't
recommend yet building automation with this tool. I think I'm hoping to make an official release at
some point where I find it stable enough that we can start to have it on the gallery and
make it an official tool. For now, it's just, yeah, an internal tool that I'm sharing. It's not
officially supported. Of course, if you have questions, you can ask via the Bloodhound Slack
and I will be happy to assist you. But it's not something you can open a ticket for in the
Bloodhound Enterprise system. Let's put it that way. And yeah, of course, with great powers
come great responsibilities. So you're going to see that with the pipeline, you can
easily modify a lot of objects. So use at your own risk.
I'm not responsible if you delete your database by mistake.
With that being said, let's get into the demo. So let me do that. Let's see here. We should have
a running install. So you did see that. Let me recap that. It did pull all the complete images.
If we look into Dockers now, I do have those three components under the composition that I
created. The images are pulled and fresh. They're in use and we have the volumes created. So
everything worked out nicely. Oops. So if you wanted to log into the application,
the first thing you have to do here is get this initial password. Then we can go to Bloodhound.
Let me see. I have a Bloodhound here. I'm going to say that I'm the admin
and give that password. He should ask me to change password. Yeah.
So that's my user password. That's not yet my
token for the API. Oops. Set a password. We're here. No data available yet. That's expected.
It's a fresh instance. So the first thing I'm going to do here is I'm going to go to,
because we want to do it over the API, so I'm not going to show you too much in the UI,
but I'm going to go to administration, find my user here under manage users.
That's the only user for now, the admin. And I'm going to go to generate API tokens.
Here I click on create token, give it a name. Let's call it admin token and save this.
So when you save it, this information is displayed. It's only displayed once and
it will not be displayed again. So the recommendation would be to put that in a
vault somewhere. I'm going to live dangerously and just do it like so for the demo.
So here I'm going to take this ID from the clipboard, put it in a variable.
I'm going to take my key this time. So the secret bit, secret part. I know you see it on screen,
but there's no danger here. It's a local instance, you know, my network. I'm good.
I'll trash that afterwards. Oops. Great job. So here, one thing for, I'll show you that,
but I'm importing this item as a secured string. I'm forcing it as a secured string. That's just
an extra bit of caution here. So it's encrypted with my DP API. And if we look at it, it just
says secure strings. So it doesn't appear in my scripts or anything if needed. So with those two
bits of information, so you see that's the ID of the token and that's my key. Same thing. You
would have to convert it to a secure string just to use a Bloodhound operator. So here I'm going to
use this new bh-session commandlet to give it the token ID, the token key.
That creates a session. Let me see. I was expecting something else here. Let's do that.
Oops. Yeah. Sorry. I didn't clean before. I'm going to do it again just so that you see
nothing in my sleeves. Oops. So this bh-session variable is where your sessions are stored,
when you create a new session. So let's do that again.
I was expecting to see this ASCII art when I create my first session.
And because I didn't get that, I knew I had other sessions in there. So this created my session.
This is the session object it creates. So simply protocol use the server, the port,
the user, your role, the edition of Bloodhound you're running, the version, and a few, let's say,
session settings that you can use. So timeout would be the default timeout for a query,
a default limit, and here cipher to clip just means when I say dash cipher in a few commandlets,
not only do you show me the equivalent cipher query, but you also put in my clipboard so I
can paste it into the application if needed. So that was the new bh-session, get bh-session,
show you the objects, set Bloodhound session, and you can set those three properties here.
So I'm going to do that here and show you that they are now modified to my needs, for example.
And that's about it. Since we only have one session, we don't need to select it. But if
you had several sessions, there's also a select Bloodhound session, and you give it the ID,
and then you can select. I'll show you that a bit later. First commandlet I want to show you
are around the API. So here I have this get bh-api, which basically pulls the API spec
and puts them into object. It'd be a bit complicated to look at, so using some PowerShell commandlets
this time. I'm just going to sort that a bit, select the method, the route, and the summary.
And this gives you a nice view or overview of what you can do with the API. So like I said,
there's quite a lot. Don't worry, it's mostly covered. But this is a nice reference if you're
wanting to run some raw commandlets. So this is what I'm going to show you now.
The whole module basically uses this under the hood. Every other commandlet will call this
invoke bh-api commandlet with the method, the URI. And these are the URLs you see here, right?
So here I could do invoke bloodhound API method get URI API v2 bloodhound users.
And if I run this, it returns this data object. So you do see that once I'm authenticated,
I'm never going to have to say the server, the port, that this is all
stored and used from the session variable.
And the object return here is always in this format data, then you get the object. So the
PowerShell way, you would have to do select expand data, and then select expand users
to get to these user object. And you do see here we have this, my admin user, basically the only
user in the application for now. As a short version, because I'm a lazy typist, this is the
equivalent command. So the alias for invoke bh-api is bh-api. You can skip the method if it's a get.
URI is positional. URI is positional, and you can use this dot data dot users here notation. So at
the end, that adds up to the same. It's kind of easier to type. And like I said, that's the
internal syntax, let's say. And the equivalent to get all the user is this get bh-operator
commandlet. That does the same thing, which you can, because it's PowerShell and the verb is get,
you could also simply say bh-operator, and it would understand that's get. So all the syntax
I show you here are equivalent. This is from the command line one. This is if I'm scripting,
and this is if I'm testing stuff internally, or some endpoints that have been added that would
not be covered yet by the commandlets. You could still tackle them with this internal commandlet.
All the commandlets have their help pages. So if I say get help, get bloodhound operator,
you will get the help page. I say all the help, the commandlets have a help page. They're not
fully documented yet. That's still something I have to do. But the idea is here, and you will
still get the syntax, because PowerShell does that for you based on the various parameters.
So it still works. Here, for example, help new bloodhound session examples.
And you would get examples on how to create the bloodhound session, which we did earlier.
Since all the commands have this bh prefix to the noun, you can do something like get command
star dash bh star, and that will give you all the commands in the module. I also have this
bh help commandlet that will do the same thing, but kind of grab the aliases and the description,
so it's a bit easier to understand. And here you see everything in the module. So all the
commandlets, their alias, the description, and the command to get examples for this command.
You can also use the dash online switch. This will, for now, it's as a guest also,
but this kind of opens this MD cheat sheet where you can quickly navigate to the commandlet you're
looking for and find some syntax and example. This is directly pulled out of the help pages,
so you would get the exact same thing if you were to run it locally.
Locally via PowerShell.
So that's it. Just a little here, a little addition, but I want to give a shout out
to Jonas for his work on the tier zero. So I added this little functionality,
the same commandlet bh help. Let me just do it like this. For the tier zero, we'll pull
all the tier zero objects from the tier zero project Jonas is working on. And if you ask it
online, you will get the tier zero asset table directly. So not directly linked to Bloodhound,
but somehow it is. So it's kind of nice to quick access to it. Okay. So we saw the creating a
session. We saw the underlying BH API that all the other commandlets would use. I showed you a
bit of help. Now let's get started really. So we talk user management. I can call this BH
operator that would list all the users. If I add self, it would list the current user you're using.
Like I showed you in the slide, there are roles and permissions, so you can get all the
available roles with the get bh operator role commandlet. And if you do bh role self,
it will tell you what role you're running at the moment. If you wanted to see, for example,
what permission does the power user have, you can say bh role where name equals power user,
select expand permission. So you're almost speaking English. That's what I love about
PowerShell. If you wanted to do the same thing for the upload only and see that they have a
different permission, that should normally match with what you saw on the slide. If you want to
list all the permissions in the application, you could also do this,
get bh operator permission to list them all, for example.
Creating users, that's something you might want to automate. So a little example on how to do this.
I'm going to first take a role. So here I'm asking for the role where the name is user and putting
this into a user role variable. You could do this differently. For the demo, I'm doing it that way.
So you do see I have this role now in this variable, and I'm going to say new blood
hound operator name Alice, give her an email address and a role. That is the idea of the role
I have here. So the idea of the user role. If I do this, now I can say Alice is the operator where
the name is Alice and put that in the variable. And if I look at Alice, you do see I did create
a user, doesn't have a password yet, doesn't have first name, last name, but we can set that.
So I'm going to say demo password. And then I'm going to say Alice set operator secret,
demo password, require reset force. Oops. So that added a password to Alice. And at the same time,
I'm going to set some properties. So Alice set blood hound operator property, first name Alice,
last name Wonderland, and so on. I'm going to change the role at the same time. So we can
have a look at all this. Oops. Yeah, that's a PowerShell thing. But all the commandlets have a
verbose switch. And I added a little. So if it's a post or anything, the normal verbose line would
be this for a normal get. But if you're using post, patch, put, it will also show the body
in your verbose. So that's handy when you're debugging or something, trying to figure out
what's not working. And yeah, we do see that the user came back this time with secret. We set
the properties. You can disable a user. So I'm going to disable it right now. You see it's disabled.
And you can remove a user. Maybe before I remove it, I show you that it exists in the application
as well. Maybe. Where's my browser? Let's close this. You see Alice has been created here. Oops.
Come back. Okay. And yeah, deleting a user. So I'm, again, what I'm doing here, so when I put
Alice in a variable, it's just a way to pass the user ID or the object, and it will grab the ID
over the pipeline. But you could completely do, you could do it differently. I could be doing
remove VH operator, and then operator ID, and pass here the ID. But I like to kind of
use the pipeline for that. And you can pass the whole object over the pipeline. You don't have
to select the property itself. So I'm going to remove Alice, because I did not say force.
So let's just say no here. And show you that if I say force, it's going to do it without asking.
Any command that has, let's say, action on the data, so deleting,
or creating a password, or stuff like this, will give you, ask for confirmation, and you can
every time say force if you're, for example, scripting, and you don't want any human interaction
with it. So here I'm just removing Alice, and now if I do VH operator, one name equal Alice,
it's gone. And I'm expecting that if I go in the application, it's gone too. You saw it disappear.
So that was creating regular users. I want to show you quickly creating an upload only. That
would be handy if you're automating your Sharpound collection, and you want to kind of
have a way of ingesting it. You could create this upload only user. So I'm taking the upload role,
putting in a variable, same thing that we did last time, creating an operator named upload dog
with the upload role ID. Oops. I'm going to create an API token for this user. So I'm saying
get bloodhound operator, when name equals upload dog, and typing it to new bloodhound operator
token, token name, API upload only. So you saw me creating a token earlier. You saw that we have to
give a name to it. So if I run this, it says, do you want to generate a token? I'm going to say yes.
I could have said force. And if we look at this secret now, I have an object here that was returned.
And you do see that we have the user ID of our user, the name of the token. And
here the token again being encrypted. There is, or encrypted, protected, let's put it that way.
There is a command lid. So here, if I say secret key, you see it's a secure string.
I added a command lid that you can read it directly. So if you do a read secure string,
it would show you the unprotected data. Now that you saw this token,
two options, or I eliminate you, or I revoke token. I'll choose option number two,
and I'll use, I won't use force. So it says, do you want to revoke token? I'll say yes.
That token is now not valid anymore. So I'm going to create a new one this time, not show it to you.
Then I can create a session, same that we did earlier with this
token this time, my upload only token.
You can see that I have this now, another session selected here with the little x,
the upload dog with an upload only role.
I could also check that. I don't use that already, BH operator role self.
So to confirm the role here, I just want to show you quickly, if I
try to request all the application for the user, the application will say I'm not authorized.
And that's because I have an upload only role. So I'm not even allowed to check on the users.
So I'm going to go back to my session one. And if I run that same command, this time it returns
the data, since I'm authorized to do it. That's about it, I guess, for user creation.
Of course, this is a recorded talk, so you can't ask any questions. But if you do have any
regarding this tool, feel free to ping me on the Bloodhound Slack at some point.
So data and ingestion, I'm going to show you how to do that.
So here, this get data collector would show you the latest version of the collector that matches
your current application. There is the import BH data collector command that would fetch these
for you. I already have them, so I'm not going to run it here. The only thing,
be careful with Defender and Sharpound. So yeah, create folder exclusion before that.
One of my favorite new features is this data ingestion over the API. So I'm going to take,
let's say I have collected this Star Wars 1 data with Sharpound. So I'm going to just say
